September 11 at 2:28 PM ·

Thank You! We had an overwhelming response when we asked families to submit 1st Day of School photos of their children!
The photos were a great mix of cute, sweet, funny and serious. Most kids seemed happy to have their photo taken, while a few appeared to be reluctant participants...probably because mom or dad insisted! We noticed a couple of stealth photos that parents likely took while their (usually older) children weren't looking! We were excited to see some staff submissions too! We saw a number of pets...cats and dogs are awesome! There were plenty of siblings, twins and a few youngsters that aren't quite in school yet. Reading what our students want to be when they grow up made us smile. Check out the album of what has been submitted so far! Feel free to add your photo in the comments if you haven't submitted one yet!

THANK YOU...to everyone who supported the 2020 ESM Spartan Garage raffle! An ESM 2002 graduate, who is ALSO a former student in the Automotive program, Brian Stoddard, won the 1969 Ford Mustang Mach 1! Brian currently resides in East Syracuse with his wife and 2 children.
This was the 15th vehicle raffled by the ESM Automotive technology program. Each year's raffle proceeds support the following year's vehicle to be restored or built. Proceed "scholarships" also help seniors heading off to college or the workplace.
We would also like to wish Auto Tech teacher Ryan Beckley the best as he heads for a new opportunity at Onondaga Community College. It was his vision and effort that created the hands-on automotive raffle project. He fostered many business partnerships during his 20 years with the district. These businesses have helped with parts and work on the vehicles and also supported our students by offering internships.
This is the first time in several years a local person has won the raffle.

ESM Senior Aaron Stoner plays trombone, euphonium and cymbals in this "Distant Harmonies Project" by the River City Rhythm Drum and Bugle Corps.
Called "Hymn for a New Day" by Drew Shanefield, Aaron was among 1,261 people registered with 330 recordings submitted. (His name is 2nd in the participant credits). They received interest from musicians in 20 different countries, ranging in age from 9 to 84. Every single video and audio file that was submitted was used in this performance, representing a harmonious collection of age, skill and training.

Every single video and audio file that was submitted was used in this performance, representing a harmonious collection of age, skill and training.

Did you know?
The census (https://my2020census.gov/) is much more than just a head count. It’s important to ESM because it serves as the basis for distributing federal assistance to schools, including the National School Lunch Program, special education grants to states and Title I aid (which provides financial assistance to local educational agencies and schools with high numbers or high percentages of children from low-income families).

We encourage you to complete your family’s Census at https://my2020census.gov/ Even if you lost or misplaced your mailer, you can still use the online link!

By law, the Census Bureau cannot release any identifiable information about you, your home, or your business, even to law enforcement agencies. Data collected can only be used for statistical purposes that help inform important decisions, including how much federal funding our community receives.

Almost 800 youth age 18 and under in our district are receiving free breakfast and lunch during the State of Emergency..that’s 8,000 meals a week!
The ESM Transportation Department delivers nearly 1,600 meals on Mondays. Tuesdays and Thursdays children get two days' worth of food., meaning 3,600 meals are delivered on those days!
That's happening with 13 bus routes that were created by our efficient routing software. Each bus has a driver, a "runner" to bring the meals to the door and a "stocker" to get the package ready for the next home. Making those meals are the Chartwells K-12 Food Service staff.
We appreciate the hard work being done by everyone to make sure that our children have enough to eat during the State of Emergency. It also gives parents a break from meal prep!
Check out the video giving you a view behind the scenes!

Fremont students have been busy in physical education classes making snowmen and castles! It is a fun way to get exercise AND use teamwork and creativity!

Materials go in the center of the gym. In small groups, students spread out around the edges. On the signal to begin, one student runs around the perimeter to earn the opportunity to retrieve equipment from the center to begin "building" a snowman or castle. Meanwhile, the partners who are not running are brainstorm ideas and begin to build their creation. Upon completion, students walk around to admire each team’s creations.

Lucinda Grathwol’s Psychology classes at ESM partnered with ClearPath for Veterans to interview, write, and edit a now published non-fiction book. Story pieces focused on persevering through life's challenges. Nearly 20 veterans are featured as well as the student authors.
It was exciting and enlightening for students to experience stories shared by the veterans at Clear Path. Serving one’s nation is a heroic action requiring one to face many unknown challenges and to persevere. Student interviewers asked tough questions and received generous answers.
Growing up today has many modern challenges through which young people must also persevere. As these two groups talked one could quickly see a connection of shared interests, such as watching movies, eating the same food and enjoying pets. Most especially, they all faced challenges and persevered!

How long does it take to collect approximately 88,690 pop tabs?

After four years, current and former students in Melissa Ferrara’s first grade class at Woodland Elementary were finally ready to donate a 30-gallon tote filled to the brim with pop tabs for the Ronald McDonald House Charities (RMHC) of CNY.
Students set a goal to fill the giant container and have seen the project through to completion despite the length of time it has taken. A core group of first through fifth graders has been dedicated to the cause the past four years.
The class made the donation in memory of Isabel whose family lives locally. Isabel’s parents stayed in a Ronald McDonald House while she fought a valiant battle.
A volunteer who has also used the Ronald McDonald House services accepted the 70 pounds of pop tabs on behalf of RMHC.

The seniors and students ate together and enjoyed watermelon and cookies. Their performance include a song on kazoos and some students speaking about how much they value visiting the seniors each month!

Congrats to ESM’s Valedictorian and Salutatorian:

Valedictorian Nolan Penoyer is the son of Darryl and Michelle Penoyer in Kirkville. He is headed to the United States Air Force Academy in Colorado to major in biology. After 4 years, he will decide whether to continue on to medical school or become a pilot. Either way, he will serve at least 5 years in the Air Force once his education is complete.

Congrats to Pine Grove Middle School Associate Principal Ashleigh Wilson, who was honored with the 2019 Secondary Administrator of the Year Award by the New York Library Association Section of School Librarians.

The award recognizes a secondary or district administrator who has been responsible for initiation, maintenance, and/or the improvement of a secondary school library/literacy program in a New York State school district during the past 3-5 years.

“Literacy is the cornerstone of all learning. At Pine Grove, we have worked very hard to develop and promote a buildingwide culture of literacy where both students and staff understand and appreciate the impact that a quality literacy program can have on student achievement,” Ms. Wilson explained.

Full story at: https://www.esmschools.org/news.cfm?story=7834&school=0

Pine Grove Associate Principal Ashleigh Wilson, is at right, receiving the award from Dawn Pressimone, left, awards chairperson for the New York Library Association Section of School Librarians.
